monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: The Nabataeans – an ancient Arabian civilization – were responsible for building Petra, carving it into rose-red cliffs between the 4th century BCE and 2nd century CE.
King Aretas IV (9 BCE–40 CE), a Nabataean king, played a significant role in the expansion and development of Petra into a thriving trade hub.

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: Petra is located in southern Jordan, between the Red Sea and the Dead Sea, near the modern town of Wadi Musa.
The city is nestled in a rugged, desert canyon and can be accessed via the Siq, a narrow, winding gorge approximately 1.2 kilometers long.

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: The earliest structures in Petra were built around the 4th century BCE when the Nabataeans settled in the area.
The city reached its architectural peak between the 1st century BCE and 2nd century CE, with key monuments such as the Treasury (Al-Khazneh) and the Monastery (Ad-Deir).

monumentInformation.title: Who Is It Protected By
details: UNESCO declared Petra a World Heritage Site in 1985 for its unique architecture and historical importance.
The site is managed and protected by the Petra Development and Tourism Region Authority (PDTRA) and the Department of Antiquities of Jordan.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: Petra was established as the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom, serving as a strategic center for trade routes connecting Arabia, Egypt, and the Mediterranean.
The structures, including tombs and temples, symbolized the Nabataean's ingenuity in water management and architecture, demonstrating their prosperity and cultural sophistication.
